children.text: Banarasi Jamdani, locally also known as the Dumpunch weaving technique, is one of the finest loom-woven art forms. Floral or geometric motifs are woven using a denser thread on exceptionally fine warp threads. The heald shaft is used by the weaver looking at patterns on paper. His ability to weave the warp freehand is what sets this technique apart. The final output is translucent and light as air.
Dr Jasminder Kaur, Assistant Professor of Textile Designing at BHU, unearths writing from Banabhatta’s Harshacharita (7th century A.D.) that alludes to Jamdani weaves.
“Pushpaptta—a flowered textile worn by Goddess Lakshmi—white as foam, waving in the breeze, ornamented with flowers and birds”.

Magasthenes, in his account of the luxurious attire of Pataliputra's nobility, specifically noted the presence of fine, flowered muslin fabrics, strongly suggesting Banaras as a flourishing hub for cotton textile production during that era.
1. Kaur, Jasminder. "The Magnificent Weave of Banarasi Jamdani." International Journal of Recent Research Aspects 3, no. 4 (December 2016): 30-36
“Sari, Dupatta, Angarakha, Jama and Chonga were some prominent products of Banarasi Jamdani.”
Bharat Kala Bhawan, BHU and Lucknow Museum have some fabulous samples of Banarasi Jamdani in their collection.
The Mughals contributed extensively to the craft through their patronage and are said to have introduced silk and zari in pure cotton weave.

One of the most ancient Persian techniques of weaving that came to India a few centuries back is gethua. It uses a multi-warp heald shaft (8-24 kaadi) in pit looms to create twilled fabrics. The patterns may be created using zari on silk or silk on silk. Common patterns are diagonal, diamond or other geometric designs. It is now possible to use this technique in jacquard looms as well.

In this technique, the pattern stands out on the fabric as if it has been embroidered. It however does not make use of the flat weave technique and the back of the fabric is not the same as the front as in the case of jamdani. Here is a picture of a naqshi jamdani dupatta: as can be made out, the pattern looks like it has been embroidered on the kora fabric.

Dampach weaving is an ancient technique that produces flat, almost painted-on motifs. Primarily used on kora fabrics, including jamdani weaves, it requires highly skilled artisans. Dampach is also employed in cutwork weaving, ensuring a flat appearance and minimizing the risk of threads unravelling after the fabric is cut from the back.

One of the most enduring and popular techniques of weaving, kadhwa (or kadhua) uses extra weft for design making. Since it involves each pattern to be woven separately, it is one of the most laborious of techniques and is time-intensive. The advantage is that the patterns look embroidered on the fabric and there is limited scope of threads escaping from motifs.

This is a weft-cutting technique involving a minimum of three shuttles going up to even seven shuttles as seen in the case of a five-colour Rangkat saree. Sometimes, only the border and palla use the kadhiyal technique to create colour patterns and sometimes, it is used across the full fabric or saree.

Ektara (Ek Taar) weave involves special technique of introducing one and two threads of silk alternately in both, the warp and in the weft. As a result, a super soft, dense but exceptionally flowy matte finish fabric emerges that is resistant to crinkling or crushing. As it uses more silk than normal fabric, and very few weavers can weave fabrics using ektara technique, this technique is generally found in Rangkat sarees, or in real zari sarees. Double ikkat Patan Patola sarees from Gujarat also use this technique. Such sarees or dupattas etc, once used, can just be folded and kept away as they settle back in soft folds without looking crushed from wear. Ektara weave was popular in garments for the royalty due to its dense weave but light and flowy structure

The phekua or fekhua technique, derived from the Hindi word phenk meaning "to throw," involves directly interweaving motifs by shuttling the weft thread from one to another. Unlike the kadhwa method where each motif is woven independently, phekua simplifies the process. While faster, phekua often results in loose threads (floats) on the backside. These are typically trimmed to neaten the fabric. This technique offers the advantage of reduced labour and time, making the final product more cost-effective compared to those created using kadhwa or kadhiyal methods

In the meenakari technique, additional coloured resham or zari threads are introduced in the weft during the weaving process to create intricate patterns. These threads are in addition to the regular zari used while weaving. When a single colour is used, it is called an alfi pattern and when three or more are used, it is called tilfi meenakari. There could be several supplementary colours used in a pattern – it is up to the imagination and skill of weavers to decide the number of supplementary colours.

Tanchoi or Tanchui weaving technique uses multiple weft threads in resham of different colors to create highly intricate, brocade-like patterns on silk. It generally has soft, satiny finish due to the use of double warp threads. The extra weft threads are woven along with the main weft thread to create a flat, smooth back with no floats.

Khimkhwab weave (also called zar-baft weave) is an ancient Persian weaving technique where the warp design covers at least 90% of the base silk fabric. The fabric is generally ornamental, exceptionally rich in craft and thick. It uses a lot of silver and gold zari along with resham to create floral motifs. Meenakari work is often a central part of khimkhwab weaves. Only a handful of skilled weavers are able to truly weave this super rich fabric.
In old times, the khimkhwab fabric was generally used to make sherwanis, chogas & royal dresses.
